Gilman Hall, the central and main
building of the new University at
Homewood, is almost completed,
and the Brady Construction ComPally has announced that it can be
turned over to the trustees before
next September. At present the
most important work under way is
the plastering of the walls and the
cementing of the floors preparatory
to laying wood on them.
The colonial hall has been under
roof for several weeks, and the entire exterior construction is completed with the exception of the
tiling of the clock tower. This
work was delayed by the late delivery of material, but is now under
way.
The engineering building is two
stories high, and as its construction
is less complicated than that of Gilman Hall, it, too, will be ready for
occupancy by next fall, if not sooner. None of the laboratories, however, are building, and it is quite
. probable that the present buildings
in the heart of the city will have to
be used in connection with those at
Homewood until the new "labs"
are built. This perhaps will compel a rearrangement of schedules,
at least for the engineering men,
under which they will attend lectures at Homewood and then come
to the present group for laboratory
work.
Several changes have been made
in the original plans of Gilman
Hall, one of which was the enlarging of the windows in the readingroom of the library. According to
the first drawings the window sill
was five feet above the floor. When
some of the trustees saw this feature and had talked with the architect, it was decided to lower .the
sill to three feet above the floor.
The change required some time, as
the brickwork and window frames
had been completed and had to be
torn down.
Many of the faculty and student
have visited the two buildings during the past weeks, and were disappointed when not allowed to
enter. Until recently, they had
been open, but when tile plastering
and cementing began, the contractors put up "No Admission" signs,
for they feared the loyalty of students who might carve class numerals on the walls.

The students of the Lniversity
and the public of Baltimore will
given an opportunity next Thursday afternoon, January 15, in McCoy Hall, to kar a lecture of unusual interest and a lecturer of great
popularity. Prof. John A. Lomax,
of the University of Texas, president of the American Folk-Lore Society, will speak on "The Songs of
the Cowboy."
Professor Lomax is a pioneer
in American balladry. For three
years Ile was the Sheldon Fellow
at Harvard University in the pursuance of the study of American
ballads. He traveled over the
United States, and -from every corner of this country where primitive life has sought spontaneous expression in song, he has personally,
with the aid of the phonograph,
gathered his immense collection of
ballads." Ex-President Roosevelt
has been interested in Professor
Lomax's work and has remarked
that "there is something very curious in the reproduction here on this
new continent of essentially the conditions of ballad growth which obtained in medieval England."
Professor Lomax has made two
lecture tours in this country. He
has everywhere been greeted by
large aid enthusiastic audiences.
He has spoken at Harvard, Yale,
Vermont, Chicago, Vassar, Kansas,
Illinois and many other colleges
and unversities.
He is scholarly, very entertaining and all who have heard him
have expressed delight. In his lecture in McCoy Hall, he will speak
of the theories of ballad origin and
authorship and will give his own
experiences in collecting American
ballads. He will read a number of
his cowboy songs, and he has been
known to sing or chant some of
these to show how the ballads arc
recited on- the frontier.

With an organization meeting
called for Thursday, January 22,
and the schedule completed, everything is in readiness for the beginning of the 1914 baseball season.
A number of men interested in
Hopkins baseball, and some former
Hopkins diamond stars will be at
the meeting to give short talks.
There is much interest shown in
the sport here and already a number of anxious candidates have been
practicing in the cage.
"Eddie" Hooper, who has coached
the Black and Blue ball players for
two years, will again have charge
of the squad, and expects to develop a first-rate nine.
Prospects for a winning team this
season are really bright. Hobbs,
who played first base last year, is
the only regular who will not be a
candidate again this year.
A number of new players will
be seen in the squad this year.
Worthington, a medical student,
who captained the Princeton nine
last year and covered third base;
"Frankie" Bowers, who starred on
the Hopkins football team last season, are notable additions.
The manager has completed a
schedule of eleven games. Five
will be staged at Homewood, the
scene of one contest being yet undecided. Trips will be made to
Princeton, N. J., on March 28, to
play Princeton: to Charlottesville,
N. C., on April 14, to play University of Virginia; to Annapolis,
Md., on April 15, to play Navy;

Everyone interested in America
and its literature will no doubt find
Prof. John A. Lomax's. lecture on
"The Songs of the Cowboy" one of
the most interesting of this academic year's talks. The recitation
and discussion of the ballads of the
."men of the West" by a true
scholar, by the president of the
American Folk-Lore Society, in itself sounds most attractive, but the
appreciation expressed by leading
students of literature mak zs it
doubly so.
Prof. William Lyon Phelps, of
Yale, said: "He succeeds to a high
degree in combining definite instruction with continuous entertainment. Every moment of the hour
was interesting."
Dean Briggs, of Harvard, wrote
him: "The more colleges that 'get
a chance at your lecture the better."
Theodore Roosevelt, in the preface to Professor Lomax's book on
cowboy songs, said of the American ballads: "There • is something
very curious in the reproduction
here on this new continent of essentially the conditions of ballad
growth which obtained in Medieval
England, including; by the way,
sympathy for the outlaw, Jesse
James taking the place of Robin
.Hood."

woke us up to the nec.ssity of
adopting it. The ease with which

The Johns Hopkins Aledical
School faculty has been enriched
by the appointment as assistant resident physicians at the Hospital of

Dr. William S. Thayer, and Dr.
Van Noord ri will assist Dr. Lewellys F. Barker.

young European physicians will be
from time to time attached to the
Hopkins staff. In return, graduates
of the Hopkins Medical School will
be sent abroad as assistants in the
Universities of Vienna and Berlin,
and in the chief hospitals of France
and England.

The Johns Hopkins Aledical
School faculty has been enriched
by the appointment as assistant resident physicians at the Hospital of
two young doctors, Carl Van Noorden, Jr., and George Minot.

is the author of many books. Dr.

Dr. William S. Thayer, and Dr.
Van Noord ri will assist Dr. Lewellys F. Barker.

young European physicians will be
from time to time attached to the
Hopkins staff. In return, graduates
of the Hopkins Medical School will
be sent abroad as assistants in the
Universities of Vienna and Berlin,
and in the chief hospitals of France
and England.
